name: Convolution
comment:
Functions for convolution
See: <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Convolution>


# Functions:

@docs convolve, convolveDirectly

values.name: convolve
values.comment:
Convolve two real number lists, using FFT for lists longer than 128 elements or direct convolution otherwise.
Threshold was determined by benchmarks.

    convolve [ 1, 0, 0, 0 ] [ 0, 0, 1, 1 ] --> [0, 0, 1, 1]
values.type: List.List Basics.Float -> List.List Basics.Float -> List.List Basics.Float

values.name: convolveDirectly
values.comment:
Convolve two lists of numbers directly by
$$ zs\_j = \\sum\_i^n {xs\_i \* ys\_{j - i}} $$
values.type: List.List Basics.Float -> List.List Basics.Float -> List.List Basics.Float

name: FFT
comment:
Functions for calculating the discrete finite fourier transform using the fast fourier transform algorithms.


# Complex values

Functions that work on complex values

@docs fft, inverseFft


# Real values

Functions that work real (`Float`) values

@docs realFft, realInverseFft

values.name: fft
values.comment:
compute the fourier transform of a list of complex values

    fft [ real 1, zero, real 1, imaginary 0.5 ]

values.name: inverseFft
values.comment:
compute the inverse fourier transform of a list of complex values
The inverse fourier transform of list Z is equal to $$(conjugate (fft (conjugate Z)) / (length Z))$$
where Z\* is the conjugate of Z.

values.name: realFft
values.comment:
compute the fourier transform of a list of real values. The output is a list of complex values.

    realFft [ 1, 0, 1, 0.5 ]

values.name: realInverseFft
values.comment:
compute the inverse fourier transform of a list of real values
The inverse fourier transform of list Z is equal to $$(conjugate (fft (conjugate Z)) / (length Z))$$
where Z\* is the conjugate of Z.
